thread.title: Phoenix concert news: Deftones, Sam Hunt, Santana, John Legend
thread.title_full: Phoenix concert news: Deftones, Sam Hunt, Santana, John Legend

title: Phoenix concert news: Deftones, Sam Hunt, Santana, John Legend

text:
The Deftones are playing a show Wednesday, Aug. 31, 2016, in Mesa. (Photo: Frank Maddocks)
Deftones and Rise Against are joining forces on a very heavy co-headlining summer tour that hits Ak-Chin Pavilion on Sunday, July 9. with Thrice and Frank Iero and the Patience.
Tickets are $30-$69.50, going on sale at 10 a.m. Friday, Feb. 10, at ticketmaster.com and livenation.com.
Rise Against issued a statement about how thrilled they are to do this tour. “Every once in a while you get to share the stage with a band so powerful they make you work harder,” it reads. “After conspiring for years, we're excited to finally share the road with such an epic band. We can't wait to put Deftones and Rise Against fans under the same roof in 2017.”
Seventeen years down the road from unleashing “White Pony,” the nu-metal answer to “OK Computer,” Deftones haven’t lost their knack for bringing the aggression with ambition and a sense of drama (which doesn’t rule out the occasional bloodcurdling shriek). They’re touring in support of "Gore," their first release since “Koi No Yokan” hit the streets in 2012, to which the Los Angeles Times responded, “Hard rock thrives on conflict and chaos, and no band has found more beauty and soaring aggression within those ingredients than Deftones.” Their best-known songs include "Change (In the House of Flies)," "Minerva," "Hole in the Earth," "Diamond Eyes" and "Tempest."
Led by guitarist Tim McIlrath, Rise Against bring a string of alternative-radio hits to the table, including “Prayer of the Refugee,” “Re-Education (Through Labor),” “Savior,” “Help Is on the Way” and “I Don’t Want to Be Here Anymore.” “A magnificent wakeup call” is how Kerrang! described their latest album, 2014’s “The Black Market,” a cathartic blend of political activism and existential exorcising. Alternative Press responded to the album with a four-star rave that noted, “Whatever meaning you take from them [the songs]…one thing remains solid—the sheer heart with which they were forged and the very visceral emotion they contain.”
8/19: Sam Hunt (Photo: Scott Gries/Invision/AP)
Sam Hunt is bringing his 15 in a 30 Tour to Ak-Chin Pavilion with special guests Chris Janson, Maren Morris and Ryan Follese on Saturday, Aug. 19.
Tickets are $51.50-$66.50, going on sale at 10 a.m. on Friday, Feb. 10, at livenation.com and ticketmaster.com .
A former college football quarterback, Hunt has written hits for Kenny Chesney (the country chart-topper "Come Over"), Keith Urban ("Cop Car") and Billy Currington ("We Are Tonight"). His debut album, "Montevallo," topped the country charts and remains the biggest-selling debut album for a country artist since 2011. It helps that it was packed with massive hits – the multi-platinum chart-toppers "Leave the Night On," "Take Your Time” and “House Party,” the double-platinum “Break Up in a Small Town” and the platinum “Make You Miss Me.”
Hunt explained the name of this year's tour, which is also a line in his new single, "Body Like a Back Road," to Nash Country Daily. “Most of our camp," Hunt says, "and from what I know about the other camps, everybody is kind of laid back, and I think the title of the tour, 15 in a 30, will reflect that,” Hunt explains. “It will still be high energy and a good time.”
6/30: Santana (Photo: Sony BMG)
Guitar legend Carlos Santana and the band that bears his name will bring the Transmogrify Tour Ak-Chin Pavilion on Friday, June 30, promising fan favorites from Woodstock to "Supernatural" and beyond.
Tickets are $25.50-$150.50, going on sale at 10 a.m. Friday, Feb. 10, at ticketmaster.com and livenation.com .
Santana's hits include "Evil Ways," "Black Magic Woman," "Smooth" and "Maria, Maria," the last two from the Grammy-sweeping '90s comeback album, "Supernatural." With with the 2014 release of “Corazón,” Santana became one of only two musical artists to land an album in the Top 10 for six consecutive decades.
Last year’s “Santana IV” debuted at No. 5, their 14th Top 10 album. Santana are currently headlining a multi-year residency at House of Blues at Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino in Las Vegas. In the fall of 2014, the guitarist released a memoir called “The Universal Tone: Bringing My Story to Light.”
5/24: John Legend John Legend is bringing the Darkness and Light tour with Gallant to Comerica Theatre on Wednesday, May 24.
The multi-platinum singer-songwriter has won 10 Grammys in addition to an Oscar and a Golden Globe award. The tour is named for Legend’s fifth studio album, which was meat with much acclaim. USA TODAY hailed it as Legend’s “most personal record,” Time Magazine called it “unflappably classy” and the New York Times said Legend “treats love as something far more complex than a panacea and a fount of perpetual reassurance, with music to match.”
The R&B sensation topped the Billboard Hot 100 with his biggest-selling, highest-charting hit to date, the eight-times-platinum "All of Me." His other hits include the breakthrough single, "Ordinary People," "Green Light," which featured a guest rap from Andre 3000, and last year’s “Love Me Now.”
Legend also appears as a jazz band leader “La La Land,” which won six Golden Globe Awards and is up for 14 Oscars.
Tickets are $53.50-$129, on sale at 10 a.m. Friday, Feb. 10. Citi/AAdvantage cardmembers can purchase presale tickets from 10 a.m. Tuesday, Feb. 7, through 10 a.m. Friday, Feb. 10, at www.citiprivatepass.com . As a special bundle promotion, every pair of tickets purchased online will include the option to get a copy of the “Darkness and Light” album. More details are available through the John Legend website.
9/9: Nickelback (Photo: Mark Davis/Getty Images)
The Nickelback Feed the Machine Tour is headed to Ak-Chin Pavilion in Phoenix on Saturday, Sept. 9, with Daughtry.
Tickets are $25-$125, going on sale to the general public at 10 a.m. Saturday, Feb. 11, at livenation.com and ticketmaster.com. A fan club presale starts at 10 a.m. Monday, Feb. 6 on the Live Nation App and livenation.com. Fans who pre-order the forthcoming “Feed the Machine” album today from Nickelback’s official online store will receive a code for early access to tickets as well as a digital copy of first single “Feed the Machine.”
Nickelback will offer a limited number of VIP packages for each show with options including premium seating, specially designed Nickelback messenger bag, limited edition guitar pick set in wood casing, parking, VIP laminate, commemorative VIP ticket, early entry and more. Fans can visit www.nickelback.com for more info. VIP Packages will be available during the pre-sale. Please visit livenation.com for more information.
The Canadian rockers, led by guitar-playing singer Chad Kroeger, cracked the U.S. market with a six-times-platinum breakthrough called "Silver Side Up" in 2001, following through with an even bigger eight-times-platinum triumph called "All the Right Reasons" four years later. The only foreign act to sell more albums in the States between the years 2000 and 2009 was the Beatles.
Their hits include the chart-topping "How You Remind Me," "Someday," "Photograph," "Far Away," "Rockstar" and "Gotta Be Somebody," all of which went Top 10 on the Hot 100. Billboard ranked “How You Remind Me” as the biggest-selling rock song of the decade.
They’re currently in the studio putting the finishing touches on their ninth album, “Feed The Machine,” set for release on Friday, June 9.
8/15: Deep Purple and Alice Cooper Deep Purple and Alice Cooper poster. (Photo: Live Nation)
Deep Purple’s Long Goodbye Tour is headed to Phoenix with the legendary Alice Cooper and special guests the Edgar Winter Band on Tuesday, Aug. 15.
Tickets are $33-$97.50 at LiveNation.com , ticketmaster.com and on the Live Nation app.
Deep Purple’s new studio album, “Infinite,” is set for release on April 7. Produced by the legendary Bob Ezrin (Pink Floyd, Cooper, Kiss), “Infinite” features 10 tracks they say were recorded “in the spirit of the ’70s.” Finally inducted just last year to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame after decades of snubs, the metal pioneers have released five studio albums since 1996, augmented by an abundance of solo work and special projects from members Ian Gillan, Roger Glover, Ian Paice, Steve Morse and Don Airey. But they plan to cover decades of fan favorites for this run.
At his controversial, taboo-tweaking peak, Alice Cooper kept the generation gap alive while the punks were still getting their chaos together (taking half their cues from Cooper). Here’s a guy who staged his own beheadings, hung from the gallows and otherwise pushed the theatrical envelope to shocking new extremes. If time has made the memory of those onstage executions seems a little silly, the extent to which his gallows humor terrified the parents of the early ’70s cannot be overstated. Without him, it’s hard to imagine a Slipknot, a Marilyn Manson or a Lady Gaga, much less a Kiss. And the records were brilliant, as adventurous as any music of the era without skimping on the hooks. Even Bob Dylan has called him an overlooked songwriter, while Johnny Rotten swears by “Killer” as “the best rock album ever made” (which isn’t half as far-off the unfamiliar would assume).
Cooper brings a catalog of hits and anthems to the table, from “I’m Eighteen” and “No More Mr Nice Guy” to “School’s Out” and “Elected.” Cooper’s touring band features the three-guitar attack of Nita Strauss, Tommy Henriksen and Ryan Roxie, backed by longtime bassist Chuck Garric and drummer Glen Sobel.
Edgar Winter has been celebrated across the globe since his 1970 solo debut, “Entrance.” With more than 20 albums, top hits “Frankenstein” and “Free Ride,” and numerous collaborative efforts to his credit, Winter continues to thrill audiences with his live performances.
5/9: The Chainsmokers The Chainsmokers will bring the 40-city Memories: Do Not Open Tour to Gila River Arena in Glendale on Tuesday, May 9.
Tickets are $21.25-$77.25 at ticketmaster.com .
The Grammy-nominated duo also announced that they will be releasing an actual album, having left it to their fans to decide whether or not they should. Each ticket purchased online for the tour includes a copy of that forthcoming debut.
The Chainsmokers are up for three Grammys -- Best New Artist, Best Pop Duo/Group Performance (“Closer” Featuring Halsey) and Best Dance Recording (“Don’t Let Me Down” Featuring Daya).
Their other hits include the platinum “#Selfie” and the triple-platinum “Roses.”
4/29: Kings of Leon Kings of Leon are bringing the second leg of their tour in support of the chart-topping “Walls” to Ak-Chin Pavilion on Saturday, April 29, with Deerhunter – yes, Deerhunter!!! – and Nathaniel Rateliff.
The Nashville brothers (and one cousin) conquered England on arrival with a scrappy, post-Strokes variation on a strain of old-school rock and roll the British rock press labeled Southern rock when, in truth, it was closer to "Damn the Torpedoes." Five years later, Kings of Leon cracked the U.S. mainstream, following modern-rock chart-topper "Sex on Fire" with the Coldplay-worthy "Use Somebody," a Top 5 entry on the Hot 100.
Subsequent hits include "Notion,” "Radioactive” and this year’s “Waste a Moment” from their first chart-topping effort, “Walls.” Along the way, they made a super-fan of Taylor Swift, who took to Instagram to crush on “Walls,” writing, “I’ve been waiting for this album for SO LONG and it’s insane, you need it in your life.” “Waste a Moment,” broke the record for most consecutive weeks at No. 1 on the AAA radio charts while also spending five weeks at the top on alternative radio.
Tickets are $29.50-$89.50 at livenation.com and ticketmaster.com .
3/12: Los Lobos at Ostrich Festival (Photo: Drew Reynolds)
Los Lobos will headline the 29th Annual Chandler Chamber of Commerce Ostrich Festival on Sunday, March 12.
They may be best remembered in the mainstream as the guys who did the soundtrack to "La Bamba." But those Ritchie Valens covers barely scratch the surface of a decades-long career that's seen their scope expanding from the roots-revival moves of their earliest efforts through the artistry of "Kiko" to "Gates of Gold," a 2015 release Magnet hailed as "a welcome addition" to the catalog.
Additional headliners will be announced soon. To purchase tickets, go to www.ostrichfestival.com .
4/8: KC and the Sunshine Band Grammy-winning disco giants KC and the Sunshine Band will perform with special guest Boogie Knights at A Night at the Ballpark at Tempe Diablo Stadium on Saturday, April 8. The concert is a fundraiser for the Tempe Diablos and Mesa HoHoKams.
KC and the Sunshine Band are best known for topping the Billboard Hot 100 with a steady stream of funky triumph in the ‘70s – “Get Down Tonight,” “That's the Way (I Like It),” “(Shake, Shake, Shake) Shake Your Booty,” “I'm Your Boogie Man” and “Please Don’t Go.” They also turned up on the biggest-selling soundtrack of the disco era, “Saturday Night Fever,” with a minor yet infectious hit called “Boogie Shoes.”
Tickets are $29.99, on sale now at go.ordermytix.com/event/ballpark . VIP tickets are $200.
Tempe Diablo Stadium is located at 2200 W. Alameda Drive, Tempe.
6/23: Queen + Adam Lambert Queen + Adam Lambert (Photo: Christie Goodwin)
Queen + Adam Lambert will launch a 25-date U.S. tour at Gila River Arena in Glendale on Friday, June 23.
Tickets are $120.25-$170.25 at livenation.com and ticketmaster.com .
After wildly successful and sold-out tours through Europe, Asia, Australia, Latin and North America, Brian May, Roger Taylor and Adam Lambert will debut a brand new show specially created for this outing, bringing fans all their favorite Queen hits, including “Another One Bites the Dust,” “Bohemian Rhapsody,” “We Will Rock You” and “We Are the Champions.”
Members of both Queen and Adam Lambert's fan clubs will be able to purchase tickets before the general public beginning at 10 a.m. Tuesday, Jan. 31. American Express Card Members can purchase tickets before the general public from noon on Tuesday, Jan. 31 until 10 p.m. Thursday, Feb. 2. Exclusive VIP Package offers are available at VIPNation.com .
4/13: Glass Animals Glass Animals have scheduled a date at Comerica Theatre on Thursday, April 13 on their way to the opening weekend of Coachella with special guests Jagwar Ma.
Tickets are $26-$36 at livenation.com , ticketmaster.com , glassanimals.eu and the venue box office.
Paste magazine says, “The backstories of the songs are as rich and developed as the band’s on-stage dynamics and energy.”
The British indie-rockers first made a name for themselves with a debut titled "Zaba," a daydream of a headphone record that worked the soulful side of trip-hop with a hazy sense of atmosphere and haunting vocals. Last year’s “How To Be A Human Being” hit the U.S. album charts at No. 20 and was featured as one of USA TODAY'S 10 Best Albums of 2016 and Under the Radar’s Top 100 Albums of 2016. First single “Life Itself,” a Top 20 hit at alternative radio, was featured on NPR’s “Heavy Rotation: 10 Songs Public Radio Can’t Stop Playing,” and the album has amassed nearly 40 million streams on Spotify since its release.
4/22: The 1975 at Alt AZ 93.3 Spring Fling Lead vocals and guitar Matt Healy of The 1975 performs at Comerica Theater, Saturday, November 22nd, 2014, in Phoenix. (Photo: Jeffrey Lowman/ The Republic, Jeffrey Lowman/The Republic)
The 1975 will headline the Alt AZ 93.3 Spring Fling with Phantogram at Mesa Amphitheatre on Saturday, April 22. Tickets are $42, available at mesaamp.com .
The young rock sensations from Manchester, England, won Best Album at the Q Awards for last year's model, a sophomore effort called "I Like It When You Sleep, for You Are So Beautiful yet So Unaware of It," which also topped the Billboard album charts. That album also sent four single to the Top 10 on the Billboard rock charts – "Love Me," "Ugh!," "The Sound" and "Somebody Else." Prior U.S. hits include "Chocolate" and "Girls."
4/15: All-Star Comedy Explosion The All-Star Comedy Explosion: Best of Humor will bring Marlon Wayans and more to Comerica Theatre on Saturday, April 15. Billing itself “a Super Bowl of Comedy” and vowing to “redefine comedy shows in Arizona,” the All-Star Comedy Explosion also features Rickey Smiley, DeRay Davis, Michael Blackson, John Witherspoon and surprise guests.
Tickets are $50-$125, on sale now at ticketmaster.com and the venue box office. Doors will open at 7 p.m., with an 8 p.m. show time.
5/16: Train The Train Play That Song Tour is headed to Ak-Chin Pavilion on Tuesday, May 16, with O.A.R. and Natasha Bedingfield.
Tickets are $25-$79.50 at livenation.com and ticketmaster.com .
Train scored a huge hit in 2001 with "Drops of Jupiter (Tell Me)" and went Top 20 two years later with "Calling All Angels." They're best known now for the comeback drive they staged with six-times-platinum, Grammy-winning, ukulele-driven "Hey Soul Sister," the biggest download of 2010 at iTunes. Two more singles from that album — "If It's Me" and the platinum "Marry Me" — went Top 40 on the Hot 100. And the hits kept coming in 2012 with triple-platinum "Drive By" and "50 Ways to Say Goodbye." The tour takes its name from their latest adult-alternative-radio hit.
6/28: Iron Maiden Iron Maiden (Photo: Iron Maiden)
The Iron Maiden Book of Souls Tour will play Talking Stick Resort Arena on Wednesday, June 28, with Ghost in the opening slot.
Tickets are $34.75-$94.75 at livenation.com , ticketmaster.com and the Talking Stick Resort Arena box office. There will also be an exclusive pre-sale for Iron Maiden Fan Club members, details of which can also be found on www.ironmaiden.com along with information on how Fan Club members can participate in the draw to be “First To The Barrier”.
The tour’s opening night in Fort Lauderdale was hailed in the Sun-Sentinel as “…a full-throttle, devil-may-care performance that thrilled a sold-out BB&T Center” while Revolver raved about how Iron Maiden’s legendary mascot Eddie dominated the Maya-themed stage: “From a walking zombie towering over band members during the set, to being featured on a host of back-drops and huge blow-up figures – the quintessential symbol was omnipresent for the entire show.” There’s even a point in the show where Eddie has his heart ripped out and hurled into the crowd by lead singer Bruce Dickinson.
Founded in 1975, Iron Maiden emerged at the helm of the New Wave of British Heavy Metal, going platinum in the States with four consecutive releases in the their '80s prime -- "The Number of the Beast," "Piece of Mind," "Powerslave" and "Somewhere in Time." They've also had four Top 10 singles on the U.S. rock charts -- "Flight of Icarus," "Can I Play with Madness," "Different World" and the chart-topping "Wasted Years."
“The Book Of Souls” is Maiden’s first double studio album and their highest-charting effort, with a No. 1 debut in more than 40 countries.
AZCENTRAL
Just announced: 2017 Country Megaticket lineup at Ak-Chin Pavilion in Phoenix
7/18: Third Eye Blind (Photo: Third Eye Blind)
It’s the 20th anniversary of Third Eye Blind, and they intend to celebrate by playing their debut in its entirety (which they’ve never done before now) on the modestly billed Summer Gods Tour.
The tour makes its way to Comerica Theatre in Phoenix on Tuesday, July 18, with special guests Silversun Pickups.
Tickets $49.95-$60 at livenation.com and ticketmaster.com .
Third Eye Blind blew up in 1997 with a six-times-platinum self-titled debut that spawned three massive pop hits — "Semi-Charmed Life," "How's It Going To Be" and "Jumper."
In addition to blowing the dust off that album, they’re planning on featuring songs from “We Are Drugs,” an EP they released last year. In addition to hitting the festival circuit (Outside Lands, Bonnaroo, Lollapalooza, Leeds and Redding), they made headlines last year with Stephan Jenkins’ hold-nothing-back opinion pieces and trolling of the RNC.
With regard to this tour, Jenkins says, “We are all about fostering a feeling of aliveness and connection. That’s why we have the Summer vibes, because our heat comes from being alive and in the moment and you can only get it when you are willing to keep it real. No one can create the vibes we do fronting over a backing track.”
4/3-4: Social Distortion Social Distortion will return to Tempe’s Marquee Theatre for what’s sure to be a raucous two-night stand on Monday, April 3, and Tuesday, April 4.
Tickets start at $40, plus fees, at luckymanonline.com and 480-829-0607.
Mike Ness formed and fronted the earliest version of Social Distortion in 1978, keeping the name at least somewhat alive through a number of lineup changes, breakups and the death in February 2000 of Dennis Danell, the only other holdout from the “Mommy’s Little Monster” days. But as they proved conclusively on 2011’s “Hard Times and Nursery Rhymes,” their first album since 2004, they still sound like Social Distortion, filtering California punk through old-school rock and roll, the New York Dolls and Johnny Cash. In 2015, they celebrated the 25th anniversary of their self-titled breakthrough by playing the album in its entirety on a tour that also played the Marquee.
9/3: Idina Menzel Idina Menzel on the cover on "idina." (Photo: Warner Bros.)
Tony-winning actress and chart-rocking singer Idina Menzel will bring her concert tour to Comerica Theatre in Phoenix on Sunday, Sept. 3.
Tickets are $126.50 at livenation.com , the Comerica box office and Ticketmaster. Visit www.idinamenzel.com/tour for all details.
After releasing her fifth solo studio album, “idina.,” last fall, the Tony-winning star announced today that she will head out on a tour of more than 50 cities from Japan to Phoenix, where the tour concludes.
Menzel earned her first Tony nomination as Maureen in the Pulitzer Prize-winning "Rent," and won a Tony for her performance as Elphaba in "Wicked." She crashed the Top 5 on the Billboard Hot 100 with a song called "Let It Go” from Disney’s “Frozen,” which won an Oscar and a Grammy. She earned another Tony nomination for her role in the musical “If/Then" and turned in a well-received nation anthem when the Super Bowl played Glendale.
4/21: Mastodon (Photo: Provided by the artist)
The Mastodon tour is set to blow the roof off Comerica Theatre with Eagles of Death Metal and Russian Circles on Friday, April 21.
It's not for nothing that an article in Rolling Stone once hailed the men of Mastodon as "America's new kings of metal." That was 2009, the year they hit the streets with "Crack the Skye," a towering accomplishment that somehow lived up to the promise of 2004's "Leviathan," a concept album loosely based on Herman Melville's "Moby-Dick." As they were touring "Crack the Skye," the website MetalSucks declared "Leviathan" the century's best metal album. Meanwhile, "Crack the Skye" topped year-end lists at Metal Hammer and Rock Sounds. The love affair continued two years later when "The Hunter" finished No. 1 on year-end lists at Metal Hammer, Rock Sounds, Classic Rock and Kerrang! And 2014’s "Once More 'Round the Sun" just added to that legacy.
A new release is on the way, and every pair of tickets purchased online includes your choice of a physical or digital copy of that concept album.
Tickets are $38.50 at ticketmaster.com and livenation.com .
The rockers have issued a statement saying, “We couldn't be more excited to pour majestic rock sauce all over your town. Come on down and help us celebrate the season of new beginnings where fresh buds bloom, animals awaken, the earth comes to life and there's a new Mastodon album to melt your face off! See you there!”
Led by one of modern rock’s most entertaining front men, Jesse Hughes, Eagles of Death Metal are unfortunately best known in the mainstream for having been the band performing when terrorists attacked La Bataclan in Paris, killing 89.
Their best-known song remains the modern-rock hit “Wannabe in L.A.”
Their latest album, “Zipper Down,” earned raves from the Line of Best Fit and Kerrang!, whose critic noted, “Jesse Hughes and Queens of the Stone Age main man Josh Homme's capacity for throwing out sexy grooves has only improved with age.”
3/26: The Adrian Belew Power Trio The Adrian Belew Power Trio will play Crescent Ballroom on Sunday, March 26, with an opening set by Saul Zonana.
Tickets are $25-$49 at www.dannyzeliskopresents.com and the venue.
Belew is a legendary guitarist who may be best remembered for his long stint as front man and second guitarist for King Crimson, signing on in time to play on “Discipline,” a New Wave-flavored 1981 release that Pitchfork ranked among the Top 100 albums of the 1980s.
He first made a name for himself in the ’70s, touring with the great Frank Zappa, playing on the “Shiek Yerbouti” album and appearing in a Zappa concert film called “Baby Snakes,” Zappa later crediting Belew with having “reinvented electric guitar.” He then moved on to touring and recording with the late great David Bowie, playing on the live “Stage” album and “Lodger” in the ’70s and returning for the Sound + Vision Tour in 1990.
He’s also played with Talking Heads ("Remain in Light"), the Tom Tom Club, Paul Simon, Laurie Anderson and Nine Inch Nails, in addition to front his own bands on a series of acclaimed releases.
8/24: Foreigner and Cheap Trick Foreigner (Photo: Bill Bernstein)
The Foreigner 40th anniversary tour will play Ak-Chin Pavilion on Thursday, Aug. 24, with Cheap Trick, who are also celebrating the 40th anniversary of their own self-titled debut.
Tickets are $29.95-$99.95, at livenation.com and ticketmaster.com .
“I never could have imagined when I set out to create Foreigner 40 years ago, that we’d still be touring around the world and performing the music we love all these years later,” says lead guitarist Mick Jones. “I can’t express the gratitude I feel when fans share stories of how our songs have been woven into their milestones and memories over the years."
This year also brings an anniversary album titled “40 – Forty Hits From Forty Years” on Rhino. The album is a comprehensive compilation of original hits and several tracks from the current lineup with Kelly Hansen on vocals including “Cant Slow Down,” “Too Late,” and the Top 20 AC hit “When It Comes To Love.” The album also features two new songs, “The Flame Still Burns,” and “Give My Life For Love,” a brand new song by Jones.
Meanwhile, Rhino is kicking off a year-long catalog promotion with the Jan. 24 picture-disc release of “Head Games.”
Foreigner’s hits include “Feels Like the First Time,” “Cold As Ice,” “Hot Blooded,” “Double Vision,” “Urgent,” “Waiting for a Girl Like You,” “I Want to Know What Love Is,” “Say You Will” and “I Don’t Want to Live Without You.”
“At Budokan” was Cheap Trick’s moment in the rising sun — Midwestern rockers captured live invading Tokyo, where the Japanese girls were responding to power-pop gems as infectious as “Surrender,” “I Want You to Want Me” and “Clock Strikes Ten” with the kind of enthusiasm Americans wouldn’t show until that album brought the mania back home.
But there always was more to Cheap Trick’s story than “At Budokan” — from the power-pop classics that drove all those Japanese girls to go wild in the first place through the more ambitious chamber-pop of “Dream Police” to such oft-forgotten ’80s gems as “Everything Works if You Let It” and “If You Want My Love.” And when they decided to capture the spirit of that first self-titled classic, right down to the black-and-white cover, on 1997’s “Cheap Trick,” they came away with one of that year’s more infectious rock releases.
Cheap Trick took their rightful place in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame last year while releasing their 17th studio album, “Bang Zoom Crazy … Hello.”
MORE MUSIC: Get the Things to Do app | Phoenix local music news | Concerts this week | January concert guide | January local music picks
4/10: A Perfect Circle return A Perfect Circle (Photo: Tim Cadiente)
Maynard James Keenan of Tool and Puscifer is set to bring A Perfect Circle back to Phoenix for a Comerica Theatre date on Monday, April 10.
Joining Keenan on the group's first tour in six years will be Billy Howerdel (Ashes Divide), James Iha (Tinted Windows, Smashing Pumpkins), Jeff Friedl (Puscifer, the Beta Machine) and Matt McJunkins (Eagles of Death Metal, the Beta Machine).
Formed in 1999, A Perfect Circle released three albums -- "Mer de Noms," "Thirteenth Step" and an album of covers called "Emotive" -- before going on hiatus in 2005. Reuniting in 2010, they did a memorable three-night stand at Tempe's Marquee Theatre, devoting each night to performing one of their three albums front to back. That tour's stop at Red Rocks Amphitheatre was captured on an album called "A Perfect Circle Live: Featuring Stone and Echo."
The tour news arrives as the members of A Perfect Circle start work on their first new studio release since 2004’s eMOTIVe. “Getting back to writing music with A Perfect Circle is a great way to start the new year,” APC co-founder and guitar player Billy Howerdel says.
Tickets are $45-$69.50 at livenation.com , ticketmaster.com and the box office. The show is presented by 98KUPD.
4/19: the xx The xx (Photo: Sacks and Co.)
Among the nicer side effects of being so close to Coachella is a lot of bands performing there pick up a Valley date. The xx, for example, are playing Mesa Amphitheatre on Wednesday, April 19, in support of the about-to-be-released "I See You."
Tickets are $40. For more information, visit thexx.info .
The U.S. dates follow a historic European tour, including a record-setting, seven-night run at the O2 Academy Brixton in London, marking the longest-ever run of sold-out shows at the legendary venue, performing to 35,000 people over seven hometown performances.
"I See You" was recorded between March 2014 and last August in New York, Texas, Reykjavik, Los Angeles and London, and is characterized by a more outward-looking, open and expansive approach. Produced by Jamie Smith and Rodaidh McDonald, "I See You" is reportedly "the xx at their boldest yet, performing with more clarity and ambition than ever before."
3/25: Roger Clyne and the Peacemakers Roger Clyne and the Peacemakers spent 2016 celebrating the 20th anniversary of “Fizzy Fuzzy Big & Buzzy” and they're sure to revisit a number of that album's highlights when they play the Pool at Talking Stick Resort on Saturday, March 25. But this year is more about getting the fans some new material in the form of the Peacemakers' first album since "The Independent" hit the streets in 2014.
When we spoke to Clyne before his New Year's Eve show, he said, "We’ve begun our sort of preliminary discussions with a really cool producer – a cat who’s in Los Lobos, Steve Berlin. He’s overseeing our direction right now in terms of production. I love his work. I love his ethos. He came to a couple of shows of ours in Portland, came backstage, hung on the bus and said, ‘Look I only work with what I like and I really like what you’re doing. I want to do your record.”
The goal is to record at Wavelab Studio in Tucson.
“So we’re hoping that our touring schedule, the studio’s availability and his touring schedule allow us to get in there in February and March,” Clyne says, “which means as soon as we’re done with these ’76 songs, we’re gonna start doing pre-production in early January here at home. It’s a pretty ambitious schedule, but we’re hopeful.”
Tickets to the concert at the Pool at Talking Stick Resort are $30-$100 at ticketmaster.com .
Coachella 2017 Beyonce (Photo: Getty Images)
Radiohead, Beyonce and Kendrick Lamar will top the bill at this year’s Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, taking place on the weekends of April 14-16 and April 21-23 at the Empire Polo Field in Indio, Calif.
Radiohead tops Friday’s bill, which also features sets by the xx, Travis Scott, Father John Misty, Empire of the Sun, Dillon Francis, Mac Miller, Steve Angello, Glass Animals, Phantogram, Mac DeMarco, Little Dragon, Banks, Bonobo, Richie Hawtin, DJ Shadow, Loco Dice, Dixon, Capital Cities, Big Gigantic, Crystal Castles, Guided By Voices and more.
Beyonce tops Saturday’s bill, which also brings Bon Iver, Future, DJ Snake, Martin Garrix, Schoolboy Q, Gucci Mane, the Head and the Heart, Two Door Cinema Club, Nicolas Jaar, Bastille, Tycho, Tory Lanez, Royksopp, Local Natives, Majid Jordan, Dreamcar, Four Tet, Roisin Murphy, Moderat, the Avalanches, Mura Masa, Car Seat Headrest and more.
pic.twitter.com/wXYbibjyiP
— Coachella (@coachella) January 3, 2017 Kendrick Lamar headlines Sunday, which also features, Lorde, Justice, New Order, Porter Robinson, Madeon, Future Islands, Hans Zimmer, DJ Khaled, Marshmello, Lil Uzi Vert, Galantis, Kehlani, Grouplove, Kaytranada, Tale of Us, Toots and the Maytals, Devendra Banhart, Tove Lo, Jai Wolf, Jack Garratt, Sasha, Real Estate and more.
Festival passes for both weekends go on sale at 11 a.m. Wednesday, Jan. 4, at coachella.com . Tickets are $399 or $474 with a shuttle pass. Camping is $113.
3/4, 4/8: Good Life Festival The Good Life Festival is more an outdoor concert series than a festival held at Encanterra, a Trilogy Resort Community. Its seventh season features Lynyrd Skynyrd on Saturday, March 4, and Kenny Loggins with Michael McDonald on Saturday, April 8.
Tickets, on sale now at thegoodlifefest.com , are $40-$80 for Skynyrd; $40-$70 for Loggins and McDonald.
From the time they hit the streets with “(pronounced ‘leh-’nérd ‘skin-’nérd),” it was clear that the Florida longhairs who'd chosen the name Lynyrd Skynyrd in mock tribute of a phys-ed teacher were serving a scrappier brand of Southern rock than the Allman Brothers Band — which is weird, because they also did more ballads. Or rockers that start as ballads, in the case of “Free Bird,” their most famous song. A 1977 plane crash claimed the lives of several members, including lead singer and songwriter Ronnie Van Zant, but Skynyrd reformed in 1987 with Van Zant’s little brother Johnny on lead vocals.
Loggins may be best remembered for his work with Jim Messina and the soundtrack smashes "Footloose," "I'm Alright" (from "Caddyshack") and "Danger Zone" (from "Top Gun"). Other hits include a Stevie Nicks duet called "Whenever I Call You Friend" and "This is It."
Over the course of four classic Steely Dan albums, from "Katy Lied" to "Gaucho," McDonald became an integral part of their sound, singing background vocals on such FM staples as “Black Friday” and “Peg.” In the mid-‘70s, McDonald joined the Doobie Brothers, helping redefine their funky R&B sound as a singer, keyboardist and songwriter on such Top 40 singles as “Takin’ It To The Streets,” “It Keeps You Runnin’,” “Minute By Minute” and “What A Fool Believes.” The five-time Grammy winner's solo hits include "I Keep Forgettin' (Every Time You're Near)," "Sweet Freedom," "Yah Mo Be There" (with James Ingram) and the chart-topping Patti LaBelle duet "On My Own."
6/11: Chicago and the Doobie Brothers (Photo: David Kadlubowski/The Republic)
Having taking their place in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame last year, the members of Chicago are hitting the road with another veteran act that ruled the airwaves in the ‘70s – the Doobie Brothers.
Chicago hit the mainstream in the '70s with a string of huge radio staples, including Top 5 singles "25 or 6 to 4," "Saturday in the Park," "Just You 'n' Me," "Old Days," "If You Leave Me Now" and "Baby, What a Big Surprise." And the hits kept coming through the '80s, with their first chart-topping entry on the Billboard Hot 100, "Hard to Say I'm Sorry," "Hard Habit to Break," "You're the Inspiration," "Will You Still Love Me," "I Don't Wanna Live Without Your Love," the chart-topping "Look Away" and "What Kind of Man Would I Be?"
They had 21 Top 10 appearance on the Hot 100 and five consecutive No. 1 albums along the way to becoming the first American rock band to chart Top 40 albums in six decades. Their double-platinum debut, "Chicago Transit Authority," was inducted to the Grammy Hall of Fame in 2014, the same year they made their first appearance as Grammy performers. No fewer than 25 of their 36 albums have gone platinum.
The Doobie Brothers' hits include two very different songs that topped the Billboard Hot 100 in their prime -- the bluegrass-flavored smash "Black Water" in 1975 and the blue-eyed soul of "What a Fool Believes," with Michael McDonald on vocals, in 1979. Other hits include "Listen to the Music" and "Long Train Runnin'."
The Doobies’ latest album, “Southbound,” features new recordings of their biggest hits with country music’s biggest stars, from Blake Shelton to Zac Brown Band, Brad Paisley and Toby Keith. Beginning with their multi-million-selling sophomore collection Toulouse Street (1972), the Doobies have 3 multi-platinum, 7 platinum and 14 gold albums. Their “Best of the Doobies” collection has sold more than 12 million copies.
Tickets are $25-$125 at www.livenation.com and ticketmaster.com .
6/10: Julianne and Derek Hough Julianne and Derek Hough. (Photo: Brian Bowen Smith)
Superstar siblings Julianne and Derek Hough will bring Move – Beyond -- Live on Tour to Comerica Theatre on Saturday, June 10.
The Houghs announced the tour today on "Good Morning America," performing at the Times Squares studio to give viewers a taste of the choreography.
Tickets are $38.50-$65 at MoveLiveOnTour.com , ticketmaster.com and the box office. VIP packages (premium tickets, pre-show parties and meet-and-greet opportunities) will also be available through MoveLiveOnTour.com .
The Houghs are promising their biggest and best show yet, with brand-new stage production inspired by the elements – earth, wind, fire, and water – which the duo have infused into fresh, high impact choreography. The pair will be joined by the Move Company Dancers for group performances in styles ranging from ballroom and tap to salsa and hip-hop.
"There is nothing like performing onstage in front of a live audience and this show is going to be like nothing we’ve done before,” says Julianne. “For those that have been before or will be experiencing the show for the first time, it will transport them beyond their wildest imaginations and expectations.”
2/18: Crush Black Tiger Sex Machine (Photo: John Londono)
The eighth annual Crush Arizona returns to Rawhide on Saturday, Feb. 18. Presented by Relentless Beats and Insomniac Events, Arizona's longest-standing EDM festival will feature Black Tiger Sex Machine, Chris Lorenzo, DVBBS, GTA, Jason Ross, SayMyName, W&W, Yellow Claw and more.
“When I started Crush nine years ago, I never would have thought it would have become one of Arizona’s most anticipated events," says Relentless Beats founder Thomas Turner. “It’s amazing to see how it has grown and become a big part of what Relentless Beats does."
Past performers at the 18 and over event have included Porter Robinson, Dada Life, Borgeous, Bro Safari, Keys N Krates, Seven Lions, Jauz, Infected Mushroom, Tritonal, Laidback Luke, Bart BMore, Max Vangeli, Harvard Bass and Richard Durand.
Rawhide, on the Gila River reservation, now hosts several large Relentless Beats events, including CRUSH, Mad Decent Block Party, BOO!, Global Dance Festival and Decadence.
General admission passes are on sale at www.relentlessbeats.com .
Passes are $63 or a “Couples Pack” of two for $100. VIP passes, which are 21-plus and include a preferred main-stage viewing area, bottle service, one complimentary drink, desserts, restrooms and express entry, are available starting at $109.
Chris Rock announces second Phoenix show, 2/25 Chris Rock has added a second Comerica Theatre concert due to popular demand. Both shows are Saturday, Feb. 25
The Total Blackout Tour is Rock's first tour in nine years.
The legendary comic broke the news in a Facebook Live video, promising all-new material and saying, “Haven't done it in awhile. Been a little busy, You know, writing ‘Pootie Tang 3’ and everything. But hey, it's time."
This tour announcement follows news that Rock has inked a deal with Netflix to produce two stand-up specials, his first since 2008's "Kill the Messenger."
Tickets are $49.50-$125, on sale now.
5/2: New Found Glory New Found Glory (Photo: Courtesy of the artist)
Pop-punk veterans New Found Glory are bringing their 20th Anniversary Tour to the Nile Theater in Mesa on May 2.
They've been called "the greatest pop-punk band in history" by Bad Religion's own Brett Gurewitz, who scooped them up for Epitaph after they walked out on Geffen. Their first album for the label, "Not without a Fight," debuted at no. 12 with Alternative Press declaring it "a reminder of why we fell in love with NFG in the first place." After two albums on Epitaph, they switched to Hopeless for 2014's "Resurrection," which Kerrang! declared "a powerhouse of a record, the brave onward steps of New Found Glory proving that hope — like pop-punk — is not dead."
